revised_title: Soot Aerosol Formation and Coagulation in Aromatic Hydrocarbon Pyrolysis
tldr: The authors studied the formation and growth of soot aerosols in incident shock flows of benzene, toluene, ethylbenzene, and indene. They found that aromatic hydrocarbons can form soot through two different routes: direct condensation reactions or decomposition into small non-aromatic species before forming soot. The study also focused on the coagulation rate of soot particles and its relation to the self-preserving size distribution characteristic of free-molecule coagulation.
